tasks.task: Discussing and implementing rotational farming practices to improve soil health and increase yield.
subtasks: Converting previous single-year crop rotation to a corn-soybean-oat three-year rotation.
Introducing oats as a seed crop and starting a seed cleaning operation (air screen and gravity table).
Measuring infiltration rates by using a six-inch ring to track water absorption into the soil.
Rotating corn-soybean-rye to waterhemp management.
Planting cover crops (e.g., rye and rapeseed) after winter crops like oats to enhance soil health.
Utilizing livestock grazing on cover crops to increase soil microbial activity and productivity.
Evaluating the yield increase (corn: 10-12 bushel/acre, soybeans: 3-5 bushel/acre) across the three-year rotation.
Integrating diversified cropping systems to manage pests (e.g., waterhemp) through rotational crop selection.

tasks.task: Ensuring soil health through no-till farming practices and maximizing precipitation infiltration.
subtasks: Measuring water infiltration rates using a six-inch hammer-driven soil probe.
Evaluating the effectiveness of different cover crop mixtures (e.g., rye and rapeseed) on water infiltration and soil health.
Adapting tillage practices from traditional to no-till for residue management and water retention.
Preserving soil structure and enhancing water percolation through reduced soil disturbance.
Planning buffer strips or vegetative areas to catch runoff and improve water quality.

tasks.task: Streamlining on-farm operations for seed production and processing.
subtasks: Transitioning from rye to oats as a seed crop due to profitability issues with rye.
Starting a seed cleaning facility (air screen and gravity table) to provide clean seed products.
Evaluating the feasibility of oat seed production and market demand for clean grain.
Implementing Good Agricultural Practices (GAP) for seed production to ensure quality and meet market standards.
Adapting marketing strategies to sell oats as a clean seed crop and diversified income stream.

tasks.task: Implementing rotational grazing systems to integrate livestock into the farming operation.
subtasks: Installing fencing to section off parts of the farm for livestock grazing.
Rotating livestock through different paddocks following cover crop harvests and crop rotations.
Assessing the nutritional value of cover crop species (e.g., rye) as forage for livestock.
Managing herd size and timing of grazing events to minimize soil compaction and maximize plant regrowth.
Observing animal impact on soil structure and potential for manure to enhance soil health.
Evaluating the financial benefits of integrated livestock and crop production through diversified income streams.

tasks.task: Adapting to changes in market dynamics and crop profitability.
subtasks: Shift from rye to oats due to declining profitability of rye in recent years.
Expanding seed cleaning operations to add value to oat crops and potentially diversify operations.
Analyzing historical yields and profits across different rotation schemes (e.g., rye vs. oats) to inform future cropping decisions.
Anticipating shifts in input costs and market prices to maintain profitability.

tasks.task: Practicing holistic farming systems to address soil health and pest management.
subtasks: Rotating crops (corn, soybeans, oats) to reduce pest resistance and disease buildup.
Employing cover crops as a multi-purpose tool for fertility management, erosion control, and weed suppression.
Using cover crops to diversify chemistries and modes of action for herbicides, managing waterhemp effectively.
Adjusting farming systems to include livestock, recognizing their roles in nutrient cycling and weed pressure reduction.
Monitoring soil health indicators (e.g., infiltration rates, microbial activity) over time to assess system resilience.
